Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a MALDI-TOF/TOF Mass Spectrometer for Molecular Structure Determination and Imaging
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Chemistry Major Research Instrumentation Program that is co-funded by the Chemistry Research Instrumentation and Facilities (CRIF) Program, Professor Michael Bowser from University of Minnesota-Twin Cities and colleague Joseph Dalluge will acquire a matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization tandem time-of-flight mass spectrometer (MALDI-TOF/TOF-MS) with molecular imaging capability. The proposal is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) characterization of synthetic multiblock copolymers essential to the development of next-generation polymeric materials; (b) moving beyond classical histology and immunohistochemistry to characterize engineered tissues and assess the efficacy of a new generation of engineered drug delivery agents; (c) identification of biofoulants adsorbed to engineered chemical sensors designed for clinical and environmental monitoring; d) determination of spatial heterogeneity of subcellular-specific autophagy markers; (e) structural characterization of bioactive proteins and nucleic acids; and (f) assessing high-speed, high peak capacity, 2D microfluidic separations to improve capabilities and efficiency in systems biology research.

Mass Spectrometry (MS) is one of the key analytical methods used to identify and characterize small quantities of chemical species embedded in complex matrices. In a typical experiment, the components flow into a mass spectrometer where they are ionized into the parent ion and its fragment ions and their masses are measured. This highly sensitive technique allows detection and determination of the structure of molecules in a complex mixture. An instrument with tandem capability provides additional structural identification power through further fragmentation of ions produced in the spectrometer. The instrumentation provided by this award will provide faculty and students in several departments the opportunity to pursue research projects using modern instrumentation not heretofore available at the institution. In addition, acquisition of the proposed instrument will enable collaboration with Anoka-Ramsey Community College (ARCC) to provide undergraduate organic chemistry students at ARCC (>50% of whom are students of color, women, or students with disabilities) the opportunity to gain hands-on experience with this technology, improving the pipeline that connects 2-year and 4-year colleges and universities.

Institution.Name: University of Minnesota-Twin Cities
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary project outcomes resulting from the award entitled MRI: Acquisition of a MALDI-TOF/TOF Mass Spectrometer for Molecular Structure Determination and Imaging (Federal Award ID: 1336940) include, but are not limited to the following: a) characterization of materials essential to the development of next-generation polymers; b) structural characterization of bioactive proteins and nucleic acids;  c) establishing imaging mass spectrometry capability at the University of Minnesota; d) collaboration with Anoka-Ramsey Community College (ARCC) to provide undergraduate organic chemistry students at ARCC (a 2-year college, >50% of whom are students of color, women, or students with disabilities) the opportunity to gain hands-on experience with this technology, accomplished via collaboration on NSF-ATE 1400885.  

Summary of specific project outcoms

Major federal grant awards that relied on access to the acquired MALDI-TOF/TOF Instrumentation include the following:

1. NSF CHE-1413862: Center for Sustainable Polymers (M. Hillmyer, PI)

2. NSF DMR-1420013: Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (T. Lodge, PI)

3. NIH R21 EB019518: Molecular PET Imaging of MET with Small Protein Ligands (B. Hackel, PI).

Publications resulting from this project:

 

  • A. K. Lewis, A. Cembran, T. L. Senkow, R. Mahling, G. T. Perell, M. R. McCarthy, C. Her, B. T. Horn, C. C. Valley, C. B. Karim, J. Gao, W. C. Pomerantz, D. D. Thomas, A. Hinderliter, J.N. Sachs (2016). Oxidation increases the strength of the methionine-aromatic interaction.  Nature Chem. Biol.. In Press.
  • Abou-Elkacem, L., Wilson, K.E., Johnson, S.M., Chowdhury, S.M., Bachawal, S.V., Hackel, B.J., Tian, L., and Willmann, J.K. (2016). Ultrasound molecular imaging of the breast cancer neovasculature using engineered fibronectin scaffold ligands: a novel class of targeted contrast ultrasound agent.  Theranostics. 6  1740.
  • Case, B.A. and Hackel, B.J. (2016). Synthetic and natural consensus design for engineering charge within an antibody targeting epidermal growth factor receptor.  Biotechnol. Bioeng. 113,  1628.
  • D. Sprouse, Y. Jiang, J. E. Laaser, T. P. Lodge, T. M. Reineke (2016). Tuning Cationic Block Copolymer Micelle Size by pH and Ionic Strength.  Biomacromolecules. Under review.   
  •  Deborah K. Schneiderman,† Marie E. Vanderlaan,† Alexander M. Mannion,‡ Tessie R. Panthani,‡ Derek C. Batiste,† Jay Z. Wang,‡ Frank S. Bates,‡ Christopher W. Macosko,‡ and Marc A. Hillmyer*,† (2016). Chemically Recyclable Biobased Polyurethanes.  ACS Macro Lett.. 5  515.
  •  G. T. Perell, A. Divakaran, R. Staebell, D. Maurine, M. Hairani, W.C. K. Pomerantz (2016). Polarity tuning approaches using versatile sulfur chemistry for peptide macrocylce synthesis.  manuscript in prep.  
  • Johnson, S.M., Javner, C., and Hackel, B.J. (2016). Development and implementation of a protein-protein interaction experiment accessible to high school classrooms.  J. Chem. Educ..   Under review.
  • Kruziki, M.A., Bhatnagar, S., Woldring, D.R., Duong, V.T., and Hackel, B.J. (2015). A 45-amino acid scaffold mined from the Protein Data Bank for high affinity ligand engineering.  Chem. Biol.. 22  946.
  • Kruziki, M.A., Case, B.A., Chan, J.Y., Yee, D., and Hackel, B.J. (2016). A 64Cu-labeled Gp2 Domain for PET Imaging of Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor.  Mol. Pharm. Under review.
  • Marie E. Vanderlaan and Marc Hillmyer (). “Uncontrolled” preparation of disperse poly(lactide)-block-poly(styrene)-block-poly(lactide) for nanopatterning applications.  Macromolecules. Under review.
  • ·S. Kirberger, S. Maltseva, J. Manulik, W.C. K. Pomerantz (2016). Highly fluorinated peptides for high signal 19F MRI agents.  Manuscript in Prep. 
  • Stacy L. Capehart and Erin E. Carlson (). Mass Spectrometry-Based Assay for the Rapid Detection of Thiol-Containing Natural Products..  Chem. Commun. Under review.
  • Kateryna Konstantynova. Communication between Streptomyces coelicolor Strains using Comparative and Imaging Mass Spectrometry. (2016). Master's degree thesis, University of Minnesota.
  • Deborah Schneiderman. High Performance Materials from Renewable Aliphatic Polyesters. (2016).  Ph.D. thesis, University of Minnesota.
  • Dustin Sprouse. Investigating the interactions of polycations with nucleic acid and the mechanisms of delivery. (2016).  Ph.D. thesis, University of Minnesota.

Major impacts of this project on society:

1. Organic Chemistry II students from Anoka Ramsey Community College participated in field-testing phase of the MALDI curriculum developed for NSF ATE 1400885 (MALDI-based Research-like Experiences in a 2YC/4YC Collaboration with a Renewable Fuels Industry Partner, Lutz PI) at UM employing the acquired instrumentation.

2. Provide Anoka-Ramsey Community College faculty development via conceptual understanding of MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry techniques and theory in support of educating students, accomplished in part through training ARCC and UW-Stout Faculty (PI and co-PIs) in MALDI-MS of oils and lipids to enable the accomplishments of NSF ATE 1400885.

3. Acquired instrumentation has been employed by groups under-represented in the sciences, giving them exposure to leading edge mass spectrometry technology. Also employed (via collaboration on NSF-ATE 1400885) by undergraduate students at 2-year colleges that traditionally do not provide such students hands-on experience with instrumentation such as the MALDI-TOF/TOF acquired with this MRI grant.

4. Acquired instrumentation employed by NSF-funded centers at UM including the Center for Sustainable Polymers and The Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC) dedicated to development of next-generation materials that will have a transformative effect on society at large.

 


Last Modified: 10/06/2016
Modified by: Joseph J Dalluge
